isis.stitle: ELECTRICAL SYSTEM TROUBLESHOOTING GUIDE - 9800 - AIR CONDITIONING BASIC THEORY, SYSTEM DIAGNOSIS AND SERVICE (WITH R-12 REFRIGERANT SYSTEM) - REFRIGERANT SYSTEM SERVICE - DISCHARGING THE SYSTEM

important.para: The fittings on the service hoses for HFC-134A air conditioning systems are standard Metric SAE quick-disconnect fittings that will work only on HFC-134A air conditioning systems (refer to MANIFOLD SERVICE HOSE SET).

caution.para: Be sure to use a manifold gauge set dedicated to the type of system you are working on. DO NOT USE THE SAME MANIFOLD GAUGE SET ON BOTH TYPES OF SYSTEMS.

step1.para: Remove the caps from both service ports.

Connect the Manifold Gauge Set making sure that the hand valves are fully off by turning them clockwise. Start with the blue manifold suction gauge hose and connect it to the compressor suction service port. Connect the red hose to the high pressure discharge service port.
On HFC-134A Metric SAE quick- disconnect fittings, turn the valves on the red and blue hoses completely off (turn clockwise). Refer to MANIFOLD SERVICE HOSE SET.

note.para: Service ports are usually marked on the compressor head. If the marking is not visible, you can identify the suction (low pressure) side by the larger diameter system hose connected to the compressor.

step1.para: Connect the yellow hose to the center fitting on the Manifold Gauge Set and the other end to the inlet of the Recovery/ Recycling Station (OEM-1380 for R-12, OEM-1418 for HFC-134A).

warning.para: Be certain that the yellow system service hose is firmly attached to the inlet of the Recovery/ Recycling Station. Refrigerant can be hazardous if inhaled.

caution.para: Do not vent refrigerant into the atmosphere. The use of R-12 is a worldwide environmental concern. Because of the absence of chlorine in the molecular structure of HFC-134A, the use of HFC-134A refrigerant will not have any harmful effects on the ozone layer of the atmosphere. Because there is not enough evidence to determine the "greenhouse" effect of HFC-134A, recycling of HFC-134A is recommended. Effective November 1995, recovery and recycling of HFC-134A will be required by law.

step1.para: Open both hand valves of the manifold on the Recover/Recycling Station. Turn the main power switch on and press the compressor start switch. The Recover/ Recycling Station will automatically shut off when the refrigerant in the system has been exhausted to the storage tank.
Work may now begin on removal of components of the air conditioning system.
